entry.title: Re: Valuation Price in Purchase Requisition App
entry.content:
Hi,
To make the valuation price field editable in the Fiori Create Purchase Requisition app, you need to adjust the configuration and extensibility settings tied to catalog-based items.

Following the steps to Make the Field Editable.
To enable editing of the valuation price in the Fiori app, consider these approaches:

1. Use Manual Entry Instead of Catalog
If you enter the material manually (not via catalog/cart), the valuation price field is typically editable.

This mimics ME51N behavior more closely.

2. Extend the Fiori App via In-App Extensibility
Use SAP Fiori Elements extensibility to modify the UI behavior.

You can enable the field for editing by adjusting the metadata annotations or customizing the UI logic.

This may require developer access and coordination with your SAP BASIS or Fiori development team.

3. Check Backend Configuration
Review the Material Master and Info Record settings:

If the price is maintained in the purchasing info record or contract, it may override manual entry.

You can also explore BAdIs or enhancement spots like ME_PROCESS_REQ_CUST to influence field behavior during PR creation.

4. SAP Notes or OSS Support
If this behavior is unexpected or inconsistent, check for relevant SAP Notes or raise a ticket with SAP Support.

Sometimes, newer versions of the Fiori app introduce changes that can be toggled via configuration.

Hope this message will help you.

entry.title: Re: CVI Conversion issue
entry.content:
Pls. have a look at https://me.sap.com/notes/2713963/E . Here it says:

What roles should be created as part of the synchronization direction from Customer/Vendor to BP?

If the standard configuration is followed, the expected roles after running CVI are:

    • For Suppliers: FLVN00, FLVN01
    • For Customers: FLCU00, FLCU01

Any additional roles needed will be created directly in SAP S/4HANA after running SUM. For example:

    • For Credit Management: The role UKM000 will be created during the execution of the FI post-conversion activities.

 

Hope it helps!

entry.title: Re: How are MT940 Transaction Keys Mapped to External Tra...
entry.content:
MT940 transaction code is external transaction code. If you import MT940 file, something will be read from the statement file and saved in the field "external transaction code", based on the MT940 type (structured, unstructured) and the list of codes that the bank uses. And then, to this codes, you can assign posting rules in SAP, in configuration in OT83 in SAP. You can also remap the external codes to different ones, usually more specific - if bank codes are too generic for correct determination of posting logic. But this remapping is possible in user exits only, as far as i know.

There is a bit of explanation in note: 3586660 - BTC/External transaction Code Extraction from Different Tag Lines in MT940 Statement

entry.title: How to Add Value help from standard/Custom VH CDS view to a field in Custom business object?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I would like to know if it is possible to add a value help (F4 help) to a field in a Custom Business Object (CBO) using either a standard CDS view or a custom value help CDS view.

Currently, the Custom Business Object app in the Key User extensibility tools only seems to allow value help through Associated Business Objects. However, we are looking to reuse an existing CDS-based value help that is not exposed as an associated BO.

Could you please advise if this is achievable?
If yes, I would highly appreciate your guidance on the required steps or best practices to implement it.

Thank you in advance for your support.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Research and Development

entry.title: Re: Global User ID and SAP IAS: Essentials for AI integration in SAP landscape
entry.content:
Hi @tskwin 

As mentioned, I'm NOT provisioning users with UUID attribute, I'm just using IAS UUID as Subject Name identifier mapped to "Custom SAML User Mapping". 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/3651184dad944aa2b361ad029a7a8cae.html

You can create the users in SAC automatically using the "dynamic user creation" option. There's no need to provision any user with the UUID to SAC using IPS in the scenario I'm mentioning. I'm just using UUID as Subject attribute for SSO. Everything is described in the help above and in the learning path.

https://learning.sap.com/courses/managing-security-and-administration-in-sap-analytics-cloud

entry.title: Re: Data Protection in C4C: Business Purpose Completed Indicator (GDPR)
entry.content: Hi Dedeepya, I get same request from a customer. They are using Consumer replication from CDP to C4C. They want to delete consumer due to GDPR in C4C. to do it, they must flag the customer as obsolete in CDP and send info to C4C. this process works well. Now, they want to differentiate consumer deletion due to GDPR and consumer deletion due to wrong data. How the replication of the consumer from CDP works to flag the consumer "business end of purpose" in C4C? Thanks. Lucie

entry.title: Re: RAP - Managed with Unmanaged Save
entry.content: Hi, just wondering. why did you choose the BAPI over the RAP BO I_EQUIPMENTTP? Also, are you creating a new application to update the equipment master data? May I know why you didn't use the standard application? Usually when we use the standard application, we can make use of released business events to update audit tables. But in your case, if both the released RAP BO and fiori app is not suitable, then your option as per MioYasutake is to use managed with unmanaged save and update the audit table from the save_modified method.

entry.title: SAP TechEd Berlin 2025: Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action
entry.content:
A couple of words about me

My name is Stephanie Jerch, and I’m a Product Manager at SAP. 

As a Solution Expert in Product Management for SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, I empower customers to benefit from its use. Before joining SAP in 2015, I previously worked for SAP Partners in consulting roles focused on Application Lifecycle Management.  

My Session(s): 

CS101 | Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action

🗓️ Wednesday, Nov 5 ⌚️ 11:15 AM - 12:00 PM CET 👉Deep Dive

What you will learn about: 

This session delves into the capabilities of SAP Cloud ALM for operations, providing a comprehensive overview of its landscape monitoring features. Participants will learn how to effectively monitor their SAP BTP environments through through the glasses of a customer. The session will highlight the latest features and functionalities. Additionally, attendees will gain an outlook on upcoming developments and works in progress, staying informed about the future direction of SAP Cloud ALM.

Co-speakers: 

Christian Niedermayer
Cross Architect, SAP SE		 Mirko Feisel
Lead BTP Plattform Engineer, Henkel AG & Co.KGaA

 

CS261 | Monitoring a custom SAP BTP application with SAP Cloud ALM for operations

🗓️ Wednesday, Nov 5. ⌚️ 3:30 PM - 5:30 PM CET 👉Hands-on Workshop

 What you will learn about: 

In this session, you will learn how to monitor a custom application on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), including instrumenting the services, configuring SAP Build Work Zone, embedding the SAP Cloud Logging service, and activating data collection in the SAP Cloud ALM tool. Monitor clicks with SAP Cloud ALM and SAP Cloud Logging and explore the latest features.

 Co-speakers: 

Christian Niedermayer
Cross Architect, SAP SE		Markus Bechler
Product Manager, SAP SE 		Stefan Lahr
Product Manager, SAP SE

Other related sessions I recommend:  

XP204 | Automate technical operation tasks for your applications on SAP BTP

Related community managed tags you should subscribe to remain informed about this topic: 

 SAP Cloud ALM SAP Business Technology Platform 

 Looking forward to seeing you: 

We're excited to have you join us as we explore the powerful capabilities of SAP Cloud ALM for operations. Let's dive in and discover how to optimize your landscape monitoring with live demos and insights into the latest features and AI innovations. Looking forward to an engaging and informative time together!

Now let’s hear from you: 

Turn the tides from reactive to proactive monitoring? What are your plans?

entry.title: SFPLS-41208 | Manage Languages | custom translations updated without changes
entry.content:
Since new 2H_2025  release has been applied to preview environment, we have inconsistent display of custom translations

in Manage languages.

some custom translations are displayed correctly in some preview environments, some are not displayed correctly.

We have a serie of custom translations to rename labels to fit process needs thru the successFactors product and we were not warned in release notes that the new manage language menu would impact existing custom translations;

we have checked in Manage Languages > Custom Translation > en_US > Current File

and the last update date is from July 1rst 2025.

my understanding was it was only adding AI capabilities to support locale that were not existent thru standard locale support.

could you please let us know if other customers are impacted by these ? 

we have over 175 custom translations so it's important sap confirms the impact of these new menu : 

does the new menu support legacy custom_translation or not ?

entry.title: What’s New on the SAP Analytics Cloud Homepage: 2025 Q4 QRC Enhancements!
entry.content:
The 2025 Q4 QRC release brings several welcome enhancements to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Homepage that make personalization faster, admin controls more flexible, and metric monitoring easier. Whether you’re an end user customizing your view or a tenant admin managing resources, these updates streamline the experience and help you focus on what matters most.

Here’s a quick tour of what’s new and why it matters.

1. Resizable Cards!

Users can now resize homepage cards vertically, horizontally, or both (depending on card type). You can better prioritize content visually to enlarge a critical story or metric card to occupy more space, shrink ancillary cards, and create a layout that mirrors your workflow.

Hover over a card until resize handles appear, then drag to resize. The responsive grid will rearrange other cards intelligently to preserve your layout.

⚠️ Note: All cards are resizable, except the Quick Action card, which can only be resized by removing its quick actions.

2. Admin-Editable Resource Cards

For tenant administrators, managing and sharing critical information just got a whole lot easier. SAP Analytics Cloud tenant Admins can now edit the resource card by adding new custom resources. This means you can curate and provide direct links to essential internal documents, training materials, company portals, or any other relevant resources right from the homepage. Streamline access to vital information for your users and ensure everyone has what they need, exactly when they need it.

From the System Administration interface under Default Appearance, administrators will see a new Edit option on the resource card. Clicking the edit icon allows admins to add or remove links with a live preview of the card. Admins can also reset the resource card to its default appearance and restore the default links.

⚠️ Note: The card must contain at least one resource (default or custom) to save changes.

3. Unified Homepage and User Profile Settings

To provide a more cohesive and efficient user experience, SAP Analytics Cloud Homepage settings and User Profile Settings are now consolidated and unified in one intuitive interface. No more jumping between different menus to adjust your personal preferences and homepage layout. Everything you need to manage your personal workspace is now accessible from a single, convenient location, simplifying your personalization journey.

4. New "My Metrics" Card: Monitor Your Most Important Insights

We’re excited to introduce the brand-new “My Metrics” homepage card. This powerful new addition allows users to set up a personalized Metric List directly on their homepage. Monitor your most critical Metrics at a glance, ensuring you always have immediate visibility into your most important business drivers without needing to navigate away from your homepage.

You can select and load Metrics List owned by you or shared with you from the file reposotory in a very easy and simple way. By selecting a Metric from the card you will be redirected to My Metrics application where you will have a detailed overview of the selected Metrics. To learn more about My Metrics and its capabilities, please read this blog post.

5. A Fresh Look: The Horizon Theme is Here!

Embrace a modern and vibrant aesthetic! The Horizon theme is now enabled and can be easily set via your Homepage settings. This integration brings a fresh, contemporary design, aligning your SAC experience with the latest SAP Fiori guidelines. Enjoy a visually appealing and consistent interface that enhances readability and overall user satisfaction. To learn more about the new SAC themes, please read this blog post.

Features Not Supported on the New Homepage

The redesigned SAP Analytics Cloud homepage brings many improvements for easier access to content and quicker insight into updates. However, a few Home features are not available in the new experience:

  • Pin to Home: Because Pin to Home depends on Classic Stories (which will be deprecated in Q2 2026) and provides far fewer capabilities than My Metrics, we determined it is not a strategic feature and prioritized My Metrics to align with our analytics roadmap.
  • Recent Analytics Application, Recent Stories, and Recent Presentations: have been consolidated into a single card called “Recent files,” where you can view all your recent items and use filters to refine the card’s content.
  • New Home Screen Note
  • Get Started

⚠️ Note: the welcome message remains always enabled on the new homepage.

System administration settings that are not supported on the new home screen include:

  • Changing the background theme
  • Changing or setting a custom logo

We recommend that you backup any of your pinned widgets and notes from your old homepage for your own records. Content within the deprecated home cards are intact in the new Home, since you can filter the results of your recent files card to show your recent stories, recent presentations, and recent analytic applications. In addition, content within the favorites tab is intact in the favorites home card. The favorites card provides more control over how you can filter and search for your results.

These 2025 Q4 QRC release enhancements are all about putting more power, flexibility, and personalization into your hands, making your SAP Analytics Cloud experience more productive and enjoyable. We encourage you to explore these new features and tailor your homepage to truly reflect your unique workflow and priorities.

What’s Next!

In the upcoming SAC Homepage release, we’re rolling out Admin-focused cards and enhancements for Admin Personas: the new Admin Overview Console, Tenant Insights, Governance & Resources, and User Activity & Audit cards provide admins with fast access to management tools, tenant health metrics, and governance content. We encourage you to regularly consult our roadmap for upcoming updates.

Log in to your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant today and experience the difference!

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud Series – Part 1: Introduction to Data Products
entry.content:
Hi @jeet_kapase, 

thanks for the detailed blog post and the great help with clarifying those topics. To stay in your example scenario regarding sales data. Would this mean (1) I would go HDLFS first with all the data, even the newest, but would then pull them to HANA Cloud for high-performance. So semantically, HDLFS would always be the persistance area in the scenario? Or (2) would I go seperat ways with data? Historical Data to HDLFS and new data directly (via "ETL" towards a HANA Cloud DWH) - if scenario (2) would be the approach - wouldn't it be necessary to then transport the new/"hot" data to HDLFS for data product generation, or AI/ML scenarios? 

Hope I am not mixing anything up. 

Best Regards

Steffen

entry.title: Re: CPI-Quicks #1: How to transform an IFlow Into an API Artifact
entry.content:
Thank you for your Question @DG 

At the moment, this serves only a semantic purpose, as the APIs do not differ from standard IFlows from a source perspective. For us, it is the initial step toward establishing a technical baseline for API based integration. When these artifacts are enhanced in upcoming releases, we will already be prepared for the new changes.

Regards
Aris

entry.title: How do you handle Terms & Conditions confirmation when external users purchase trainings in LMS?
entry.content:
Hi everyone!

We received feedback from our Legal department regarding the purchase of trainings in our SAP SuccessFactors LMS.

In our setup, external users can register on the learning portal and purchase trainings. During registration, they must already accept the platform’s Terms & Conditions.

According to Legal, even though users accept the conditions when they first register, they should confirm agreement again when purchasing a specific training. The reasoning is that each training purchase constitutes a separate contract. They suggested implementing a “checkbox solution” at the point of purchase, but also mentioned that a simple text reference to the consent agreement would be sufficient.

We’d like to know if other organizations have implemented this in practice within SAP SF LMS.

Do you display or reference the consent statements during each purchase flow? If so, how? Or do you rely on the general system behavior for consent acceptance and handle the contractual aspect differently?

Any feedback is highly appreciated. Thank you & best regards

Julia

entry.title: Re: Accessing long text of SAP Master data Objects or fields in S4 Hana through a CDS View
entry.content:
All replicated SAPscript long texts in table esh_sr_ltxt are missing line breaks. So, this might not be the convenient all-purpose replacement it seemed to be.

Of course, CDS view I_TextObjectPlainLongText doesn't promise anything other than plain text. And in the originally intended context of (enterprise) search this seems to be fine.

However, the view is now part of the VDM of released BOs like I_MaintenanceOrderTP (S/4HANA 2023). Surely, line breaks should be supported there. What am I missing?

entry.title: BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_TT does not show errors if no stock available (nor COGI!?)
entry.content:
Dear Experts

 

We have been using  co6n and for a long time and it works properly. I am trying to use the bapi BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_TT to do the same, mostly consumption of materials, in case there is an error (stock is not enough for instance) the movement should go to COGI. We use SP HANA since 2024.

I am testing in Se37 with a test sequence of BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_TT and later BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT with the "X"

I started with a simple entry in tables TIMETICKETS (record with confirmation number and little more, no yield) GOODSMOVEMENTS and also LINK_CONF_GOODSMOV table.

When I do a confirmation with a simple good movement of 1 unit (I have 10.000 in stock in my test system) all goes well apparently. At least the movement 261 is shown in MB51 and the confirmation is recorded. Only it’s a bit weird that in CORT I do not see the movement attached to the confirmation but for the rest, even the reservation is reduced etc.

The trouble is when I test a wrong movement to create a COGI or “some error”. For instance I enter quantity 999999 in the BAPI to create a cogi.

I get no error or message in BAPI, even it says that the confirmation has been saved. Later after commit, nothing happens.

If I do a similar thing in the same order, it goes to COGI.

SO I am a bit confused 😞

entry.title: SAP QM results recording : attaching documents
entry.content:
Dear all,

I am planning to connect SAP QM with a web application.
Quality control result recording will be performed in the web app, and the recorded results should be stored in SAP QM.

Additionally, the possibility to attach documents (e.g. images, PDFs, etc.) at the MIC level during result recording will be enabled.

My questions are:

Which BAdI can be used to achieve this integration?

Where are the attached documents stored in SAP QM? Is there a specific table for them?

Thank you in advance for your help.

Best regards,
Soufiane

entry.title: Re: How are MT940 Transaction Keys Mapped to External Transaction Keys in SAP Bank Statement Process
entry.content:
Hello @MalgorzataS,

Thanks for the response,

Suppose my bank statement (attached) uses field 61 as the transaction key. My requirement is to have separate G/L accounts for:

  • Incoming bank transfer

  • Incoming cheque

  • Outgoing transfer

  • Outgoing cheque

I have created four external transaction keys in SAP for these scenarios and defined the corresponding posting (processing) rules.

My question:
How does SAP determine which external transaction code is mapped to a specific transaction from the bank statement file? For example, how does SAP know whether a transaction in field 61 should be posted using the external key for incoming transfer or outgoing cheque? Is the mapping entirely based on configuration, or does SAP use logic from the MT940 file’s content (like amount sign or code combinations)? What setup or mapping is required to ensure each transaction is posted to the correct G/L account?

Any clarification on the technical flow or config steps for this mapping would be helpful.

Best Regards,

Nithin

entry.title: Re: HR Access to Performance Forms
entry.content:
Hi - We permissioned reporting. This is the path for our HR colleagues to access in progress or completed forms:

Report Center > Classic Reporting > All Reports by Type > Detailed Document Search

The Detail Document Search results allow you to Generate Report as a read-only version of the form. Traditional excel exports are also available.

entry.content: I wanted to accomplish this same thing with Pay Scale Level AND Pay Grade Level. I found this KBA today: 2559785 - How to Deactivate / Delimit PayScaleLevel - SAP for Me. I haven't asked for this change yet, but I plan to, hoping it might be a viable solution for us.

entry.title: Re: SF LMS Item Completion Rule for Assignment Profile
entry.content: Sorry @karenperez.  My experience shows that, in the current release,  the required operator for Item Completion is EQUALS. However, in some cases SuccessFactors changes this to MATCHES when you save the rules. This is a known issue acc. to Copilot. One workaround iIfound is to go back and copy one of your APs that works: copy everything including the item. Then, in the copy, swap out the item for the new desired one. Save the rules. That can sometimes preserve your EQUALS operator. I hope that SAP is trying to fix this 😞 .

entry.title: Re: Search for the BAdI to trigger a notification after s...
entry.content: Hi, is this BADI released? Ideally, the approach for this would be to use local/remote event consumption. However, currently in S4 2023, local event consumption is only supported for custom RAP BOs. The released events for standard RAP BOs cannot be consumed directly via local event consumption.

entry.title: Re: Success factor beginning

I've looked at a lot of them, and most are terrible.  They are not designed for LMS administrators. Stick with the SAP ones as suggested above. Also check out the free videos from TalenTeam.  Good luck, I had a difficult time finding training on administering the Learning module.

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Item is not matched to Invoice Item in...
entry.content: Hello Linda, are there plans to expand the matching of purchase order items and invoice items to include data fields such as the Global Trade Item Number (GTIN) and/or the supplier material number? These two values appear on our suppliers' invoices and are much more suitable as matching objects than quantities, prices, and short descriptions, which in some cases may even be identical across multiple invoice items.

entry.title: Recommendations requested: Training Item Organization
entry.content:
We have three modules of internally-developed L&D trainings, which are optional for employees to take. Each module is set up as a curriculum, and we have both in-person and virtual versions of each curriculum. Each module contains 4-6 separate learning items within it.

This was all developed and implemented before my time, but I've been tasked with cleaning up our LMS. We want to be able to streamline the presentation of these modules, ideally just having one instance of each module that contains all content for folks to register for whether they are attending virtually or in-person. Additionally, we'd like to be able to present Module 1 to everyone on the new learning home page as "important learning," but make modules 2 and 3 searchable by all employees. What is the best recommendation for how to do so?

Happy to answer questions and provide additional context/clarification. Thanks in advance for any support!

entry.title: SAP Build Apps Redirects to Initial Page in Work Zone on Browser Refresh
entry.content:
SAP Build Apps Redirects to Initial Page in Work Zone on Browser Refresh

 

Hello Community,

I am experiencing an issue with state management and routing when running an SAP Build Apps application deployed within SAP Build Work Zone Standard Edition (Trial Account).

Configuration and Setup:

  1. I created and deployed an SAP Build Apps application on sap build Work zone.

  2. In the Work Zone, I updated the Channel Manager and added the HTML5 Application in the content mange and then added it to my catalog. 

The Problem:

The application launches correctly from the tile and operates as expected. However, the application appears to be running without proper URL routing synchronization with the Work Zone shell:

  • When I navigate to a secondary page within the Build App, the URL in the browser address bar remains unchanged.

  • Consequently, if I perform a browser refresh (F5) while on a secondary page, the application redirects back to the application's initial/Home Page.

entry.title: Ariba Sourcing: how to send prices to external system when Unit Price has more than 2 decimals?
entry.content:
We are currently facing an issue related to unit price precision in a sourcing event in SAP Ariba.

In our current setup, some materials have a unit price defined with 4 decimal places (e.g., 0.1234 EUR per piece). This level of precision is important for business accuracy. However, SAP S/4HANA only accepts unit prices with a maximum of 2 decimal places, which causes the integration between Ariba and S/4HANA to fail when processing such sourcing events and generating contracts.

In the past (before using SAP Ariba), this was resolved by defining the price in contract in SAP S/4 HANA for 100 pieces instead of 1, allowing for a price like 12.34 EUR per 100 pcs, which works within S/4HANA’s limits.

Our understanding is that there is no standard functionality or recommended workaround that would allow us to collect prices per 1 piece in SAP Ariba and 4 decimal and have an award sent to SAP S/4 HANA with price per 100 pieces and 2 decimals.

For that reason we are exploring a solution where price per 100 pieces is collected in SAP Ariba so that later award can be sent to external system and we can have a contract creates in SAP S/4 HANA with price per 100 pieces.

For example: price per 1 piece is 0.4455 EUR.  Overall quantity is 100 000 pieces.
So our only option would be to ask supplier in Ariba for price for 100 pieces (in this example it would be 44.55 EUR and it would be accepted by SAP S/4HANA). 
So after award we could send prices to external system to create a quantity contract for 100 000 pieces with price  44.55 per 100 pieces. 

Is possible to configure SAP Ariba event so that the above would be possible? If so, how can this be done?
Do you have any other suggestions on how this should be addressed?

entry.title: Hello SAP Community
entry.content: Hello, I'm Sandra, a Solution Owner, and I'm excited to be a part of the SAP Community.

entry.title: Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application
entry.content:
Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application and Integrating with SAP Build Work Zone

In this tutorial, we will guide you through the process of creating a custom Joule skill tailored to a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) based Fiori application. You’ll learn how to deploy this skill and enable Joule functionality within SAP Build Work Zone, enabling intelligent, conversational interaction within your enterprise apps.

Step 1: Configure a Destination in Your SAP BTP Subaccount

Begin by setting up a destination in your SAP BTP subaccount where Joule Studio is subscribed. This destination should point to the endpoint of your CAP service.

Ensure you add the following property in the additional settings:

sap.processautomation.enabled = true

 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true

 

sap.build.usage = CAP

This configuration allows SAP Build to consume the service.

 

Step 2: Add Destination in the Control Tower

Next, go to the Control Tower section within the SAP Build Process Automation cockpit and add the destination you just created.

 

Step 3: Start a New Action Project

Navigate to the Actions tab and click Create to initiate a new action project.

 

Step 4: Choose SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

Since your action will interact with a CAP service, select SAP Cloud Application Programming Model as the project type.

 

Step 5: Select and Configure Service Endpoints

  • A list of available service endpoints from your CAP application will be displayed. Pick the desired endpoint and complete the necessary configuration.

 

  • Click on Next
  • Give You Project Name

 

 

  • Create Action for the ODATA Service
  • Select required endpoint and configure it.

  

 

  • Test the Endpoint with destination and see the output

 

 

  • Create similar action for the all department data and test it

 

 

 

Step 6: Build and Deploy Your Joule Skill

  • Click Create to set up the action project. Then, select the Joule Skill tile and create the skill

 

  • Open the above skill and again create joule skill and give name and description

 

  • Open he above skill and add action like below

 

  • Configure destination for this action

 

  • Configure the Output Variable for this action

 

  • Set the output variable on clicking on End
  • Create similar joule skill for department by following above steps

 

  • Once you finish, Save, Release

 

 

 

 

  • After Releasing Click on Deploy and choose the environment that you want

 

 

Step 7: Enable Shared Access

  • Go to home page and click on Control Tower
  • Choose Environment
  • Select Environment that we choose for our Joule Skill you will see your deployed skill there

 

 

  • Click on Setting and Enable shared option

Step 8: Connect Joule with SAP Build Work Zone

At the global account level, access the Formations area. Select Include Systems and add SAP Build Work Zone from the appropriate subaccount.

Activate these features:

  • Enable Joule Icon in Integrated System

 

Step 9: Confirm Integration and Activate Joule

Verify your setup under System Landscape → Formation.

Then, log into your SAP Build Work Zone site.

Step 10: Validate Your Skills

Open your Work Zone site to see the Joule Icon appear at the top.

 

Test your deployed skill by typing queries related to your CAP application and observe how Joule responds.

 

 

 

Summary

Integrating custom Joule Skills into SAP Build Work Zone allows you to embed conversational AI directly within your business applications. This guide demonstrated how to connect a CAP-based Fiori app, configure necessary destinations, deploy custom skills, and enable Joule for seamless interaction.

By following these steps, you enable end users to engage naturally with enterprise data and processes—making your applications smarter, more interactive, and easier to use.

entry.title: Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution
entry.content:
Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution

Transforming how AI systems collaborate in modern enterprise environments

 

The enterprise AI landscape is experiencing a paradigm shift. While individual AI agents have proven their worth in specific domains, the real transformation happens when these intelligent systems can seamlessly collaborate, share knowledge, and coordinate complex workflows. Enter two revolutionary protocols that are reshaping how we think about AI integration: Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A).

The Integration Challenge: Breaking Down AI Silos

Picture this: You're managing an e-commerce platform with specialized AI agents for inventory management, fraud detection, customer recommendations, and order fulfillment. Each agent performs exceptionally within its domain, but when a customer wants to modify a large order that was flagged for unusual purchasing patterns while using a promotional code—suddenly your streamlined system becomes a coordination nightmare.

This scenario illustrates the fundamental challenge facing modern enterprises: AI agents operating in isolation. Without standardized communication protocols, organizations struggle with:

  • Integration Complexity: Each new AI tool requires custom integration work, consuming valuable development resources
  • Data Inconsistency: Different systems use varying data formats, leading to translation errors and processing delays
  • Workflow Fragmentation: Multi-step processes require manual intervention to bridge gaps between AI systems
  • Scalability Limitations: Adding new capabilities means exponentially more integration points to maintain

The result? Expensive, brittle AI implementations that fail to deliver their full potential.

Model Context Protocol (MCP): The Universal AI Language

 

Model Context Protocol addresses the first half of this challenge by creating a standardized way for AI applications to communicate with external systems and data sources. Developed by Anthropic, MCP serves as a universal translator that eliminates the need for custom integrations.

How MCP Transforms System Integration

Traditional AI integration requires developers to:

  • Learn each system's unique API structure
  • Handle different authentication methods
  • Parse varying data formats
  • Maintain separate codebases for each integration

MCP changes this by providing a unified interface that abstracts away system-specific complexities. Think of it as having a universal remote control that works with every device in your smart home, regardless of brand or model.

Core MCP Components

MCP Host: Acts as the central coordination hub, managing all communication between AI clients and external systems.

MCP Client: Represents your AI application that needs to access external resources or capabilities.

MCP Server: Exposes specific functionalities, data sources, or services in a standardized format that any MCP client can understand.

What MCP Servers Provide

Tools: Executable functions that AI agents can discover and use dynamically. For example, a customer service AI could discover and invoke tools for order lookup, refund processing, or inventory checking without needing pre-programmed knowledge of each system.

Resources: Access to both static and dynamic data sources. This might include real-time inventory levels, customer databases, product catalogs, or analytical reports—all accessible through a consistent interface.

Prompts: Reusable, parameterized templates that maintain consistency across different AI interactions while allowing for customization based on specific contexts.

Real-World MCP Benefits: E-commerce Transformation

Consider an online retailer implementing MCP across their AI ecosystem:

Before MCP: Their recommendation engine needed separate integrations with the inventory system, customer database, pricing engine, and analytics platform. Each integration required months of development and ongoing maintenance.

After MCP: The recommendation engine simply queries the MCP ecosystem for "customer profile," "available products," and "pricing data." The MCP servers handle all the complexity of connecting to underlying systems, transforming data formats, and managing authentication.

Result: Development time reduced from months to weeks, maintenance overhead decreased by 60%, and new AI capabilities can be added without touching existing integrations.

MCP's Business Impact

Accelerated Development: Teams can focus on AI logic rather than integration plumbing, reducing time-to-market for new AI features by up to 70%.

Enhanced Reliability: Standardized interfaces reduce integration bugs and improve system stability.

Future-Proofing: When underlying systems change, only the MCP server needs updating—all connected AI clients continue working without modification.

Cost Efficiency: Reduced integration complexity means lower development and maintenance costs, with some organizations reporting 50% savings on AI infrastructure expenses.

Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A): Orchestrating AI Collaboration

 

While MCP solves the AI-to-system challenge, Agent-to-Agent Protocol tackles the equally important problem of AI-to-AI communication. A2A enables different AI agents to discover, communicate, and coordinate with each other to handle complex, multi-step workflows.

The Multi-Agent Coordination Challenge

Modern business processes rarely fit within a single AI agent's capabilities. Consider a customer support scenario where a client reports a billing error on their account. This seemingly simple request actually requires coordination between:

  • Customer Service AI: To understand the query and manage the interaction
  • Billing System AI: To identify and analyze the billing discrepancy
  • Fraud Detection AI: To ensure the request isn't part of a fraudulent pattern
  • Account Management AI: To determine appropriate remediation steps

Without A2A, each handoff between agents requires manual intervention or custom integration work.

A2A's Coordination Framework

Dynamic Discovery: Agents can automatically discover other agents' capabilities through standardized "Agent Cards" that describe what each agent can do, what inputs it needs, and what outputs it provides.

Role-Based Organization: A2A defines clear roles—coordinators who manage workflows, specialists who handle specific tasks, and observers who monitor and provide insights.

Task Lifecycle Management: Every interaction follows a structured lifecycle from task creation through completion, with standardized status updates and error handling.

Flexible Communication: Agents can exchange various content types—text, images, structured data, or complex multimedia—through a unified messaging framework.

Transformative Healthcare Use Case

Let's explore how A2A revolutionizes healthcare coordination—a domain where precise, timely collaboration literally saves lives:

Scenario: A patient arrives at the emergency department with chest pain.

Traditional Approach:

  • Triage nurse manually enters patient data into multiple systems
  • Various specialists are paged individually
  • Lab orders are placed through separate systems
  • Results are manually communicated between departments
  • Treatment decisions involve multiple phone calls and consultations

A2A-Enabled Approach: The Emergency Coordinator Agent automatically orchestrates the entire process:

  1. Immediate Assessment: Delegates initial evaluation to the Triage AI, which processes symptoms and assigns priority
  2. Parallel Specialist Coordination: Simultaneously engages Cardiology AI for cardiac risk assessment, Lab AI for stat blood work orders, and Radiology AI for imaging protocols
  3. Real-Time Collaboration: As results become available, each specialist AI provides recommendations that are automatically integrated into a comprehensive assessment
  4. Coordinated Decision Making: The Treatment Planning AI synthesizes all inputs to recommend optimal care pathways
  5. Resource Optimization: Bed Management AI ensures appropriate room assignment while Pharmacy AI prepares necessary medications

Outcome: What traditionally took hours of coordination happens in minutes, with improved accuracy and reduced human error.

A2A's Healthcare Benefits

Reduced Response Times: Emergency protocols that previously required 30-45 minutes now complete in under 10 minutes.

Improved Accuracy: Standardized communication eliminates transcription errors and ensures all relevant information is considered.

Enhanced Care Quality: Parallel processing allows for more comprehensive evaluation without delays.

Resource Optimization: Intelligent coordination prevents resource conflicts and optimizes staff utilization.

Audit Trail: Every decision and communication is logged, providing complete visibility into care processes.

The Synergy: MCP + A2A = Enterprise AI Excellence

The true power emerges when MCP and A2A work together, creating an ecosystem where AI agents can seamlessly access any enterprise system while coordinating sophisticated workflows with other agents.

Manufacturing Excellence Example

Consider a smart manufacturing facility where quality control, predictive maintenance, supply chain, and production planning agents work together:

MCP Integration: Each agent accesses manufacturing data through standardized interfaces—production metrics, equipment sensors, inventory levels, and quality reports—without needing to understand the underlying industrial systems.

A2A Coordination: When the predictive maintenance agent detects potential equipment failure, it automatically:

  • Alerts the production planning agent to adjust schedules
  • Informs the supply chain agent to expedite replacement parts
  • Notifies the quality control agent to increase inspection frequency
  • Coordinates with the facility management agent to schedule maintenance windows

Result: Unplanned downtime reduced by 80%, maintenance costs decreased by 40%, and product quality improved through proactive interventions.

Financial Services Transformation

In banking, compliance, risk management, customer service, and fraud detection agents collaborate to provide comprehensive financial services:

Real-Time Risk Assessment: When a customer applies for a loan, the application automatically triggers parallel processing across multiple AI agents—credit analysis, fraud detection, regulatory compliance, and market risk assessment—with results synthesized in minutes rather than days.

Automated Compliance: Regulatory changes automatically propagate through the agent network, with each agent updating its decision-making criteria and reporting mechanisms without human intervention.

Enhanced Customer Experience: Customer service agents can instantly access comprehensive customer profiles while coordinating with specialized agents for investment advice, loan modifications, or dispute resolution.

Strategic Implementation Benefits

Organizational Advantages

Scalability Without Complexity: Adding new AI capabilities becomes as simple as plugging in new agents—the underlying infrastructure handles all communication and coordination automatically.

Reduced Technical Debt: Standardized protocols eliminate the accumulation of custom integrations that become expensive to maintain over time.

Faster Innovation: Teams can experiment with new AI agents without worrying about integration challenges, accelerating the pace of innovation.

Improved ROI: Organizations typically see 3x faster deployment of new AI capabilities and 60% reduction in integration costs.

Operational Excellence

Enhanced Reliability: Built-in error handling, circuit breakers, and failover mechanisms ensure system resilience even when individual components fail.

Better Visibility: Comprehensive monitoring and logging provide unprecedented insight into AI system performance and decision-making processes.

Simplified Management: Centralized configuration and monitoring reduce operational complexity while improving control over AI behaviors.

Compliance Readiness: Standardized audit trails and governance frameworks make it easier to meet regulatory requirements.

Addressing Implementation Challenges

Security and Trust Considerations

Authentication and Authorization: Both protocols include robust security frameworks to ensure only authorized agents can access specific resources or communicate with other agents.

Data Privacy: Built-in privacy controls protect sensitive information while enabling necessary collaboration between agents.

Audit and Compliance: Comprehensive logging and monitoring capabilities support regulatory requirements and internal governance policies.

Performance Optimization

Efficient Communication: Both protocols are designed for high-performance scenarios with minimal overhead and optimized message formats.

Load Balancing: Intelligent distribution of work across agent networks prevents bottlenecks and ensures optimal resource utilization.

Caching and Optimization: Smart caching mechanisms reduce redundant operations and improve overall system responsiveness.

Change Management

Gradual Adoption: Organizations can implement MCP and A2A incrementally, starting with high-value use cases and expanding over time.

Training and Education: Success requires investment in team education to help developers and administrators understand the new paradigms.

Cultural Shift: Moving from custom integrations to standardized protocols requires organizational commitment to new development approaches.

Future Outlook: The Evolution of AI Collaboration

Emerging Trends

Multi-Modal Communication: Next-generation implementations will support rich media communications, enabling agents to share images, video, audio, and complex data visualizations as part of their coordination efforts.

Federated Learning: Agents will be able to share and improve their models collaboratively while maintaining data privacy and security.

Self-Healing Networks: Advanced implementations will automatically detect and recover from failures, redistributing work and spawning replacement agents as needed.

Cross-Organization Collaboration: Future versions may enable secure collaboration between agents across organizational boundaries, creating industry-wide AI ecosystems.

Industry-Specific Evolution

Healthcare: Integration with medical devices, electronic health records, and regulatory systems will enable comprehensive patient care coordination.

Financial Services: Real-time market data integration and regulatory compliance automation will transform trading, lending, and risk management.

Manufacturing: Integration with IoT sensors, robotics, and supply chain systems will enable fully autonomous production optimization.

Retail: Seamless integration across online and offline channels will create truly omnichannel customer experiences.

Measuring Success: Key Performance Indicators

Technical Metrics

Integration Speed: Time to integrate new AI capabilities reduced from months to weeks

System Reliability: Uptime improvements of 99.9% or higher through robust error handling

Performance Optimization: Response time improvements of 40-60% through efficient communication protocols

Maintenance Reduction: 50-70% reduction in integration maintenance overhead

Business Metrics

Time to Market: Accelerated deployment of new AI features and capabilities

Cost Savings: Reduced development and maintenance costs through standardization

Innovation Velocity: Increased rate of AI experimentation and deployment

Competitive Advantage: Enhanced ability to respond quickly to market changes and opportunities

Getting Started: Practical Implementation Steps

Phase 1: Assessment and Planning

Current State Analysis: Evaluate existing AI implementations and identify integration pain points

Use Case Prioritization: Select high-value scenarios where MCP and A2A can deliver immediate benefits

Technical Readiness: Assess infrastructure and team capabilities for protocol implementation

Phase 2: Pilot Implementation

Limited Scope Deployment: Start with a single, well-defined use case to prove value and learn lessons

Performance Baseline: Establish metrics for comparing before and after implementation results

Team Training: Invest in education and skill development for development and operations teams

Phase 3: Scaled Deployment

Gradual Expansion: Systematically extend implementation to additional use cases and systems

Governance Framework: Establish policies and procedures for managing the expanded AI ecosystem

Continuous Optimization: Regular performance review and optimization of agent interactions and system performance

Conclusion: The Collaborative AI Future

The integration of Model Context Protocol and Agent-to-Agent Protocol represents a fundamental shift in how we architect and deploy enterprise AI systems. By standardizing communication between AI and enterprise systems (MCP) and enabling sophisticated coordination between AI agents (A2A), organizations can unlock the full potential of collaborative artificial intelligence.

The transformation is profound:

  • Development cycles shortened from months to weeks
  • Maintenance overhead reduced by 50-70%
  • System reliability improved to 99.9%+ uptime
  • Innovation velocity increased by 3x or more

The opportunity is immediate:

  • Protocols are mature and ready for enterprise deployment
  • Implementation can begin with high-value, low-risk pilot projects
  • Benefits compound as more agents and systems join the ecosystem

The competitive advantage is significant:

  • Organizations that adopt these protocols will be able to deploy AI capabilities faster and more reliably than competitors
  • The ability to coordinate complex, multi-agent workflows will become a key differentiator
  • Standardized approaches will enable innovation at unprecedented scale

Whether you're in healthcare, finance, manufacturing, or retail, MCP and A2A provide the foundation for building sophisticated, resilient, and scalable AI ecosystems that can transform how your organization operates and competes.

The future of enterprise AI isn't about individual agents working in isolation—it's about orchestrated networks of specialized agents working together seamlessly to deliver exceptional business outcomes. Start your journey toward collaborative AI excellence today.

Key Resources:

  • Strategic Planning: Begin with a comprehensive assessment of your current AI landscape and identify high-value integration opportunities
  • Technical Implementation: Consider partnering with experienced system integrators who understand both protocols
  • Change Management: Invest in team education and organizational change management to ensure successful adoption
  • Continuous Improvement: Plan for ongoing optimization and expansion of your collaborative AI ecosystem

entry.title: Re: Search for the BAdI to trigger a notification after s...
entry.content: @Ryan-Crosby, I think the BADI is our better alternative for now, until SAP release the local RAP BO events for Sales Order (it's in the roadmap for 2025). Ideally, at this point (i.e., S4 2023), the clean core option would be to use remote business events but I figured not everyone is subscribed to SAP event mesh/BTP ABAP.

entry.title: Re: DM - iXBRL issue from antivirus scanner on server folder
entry.content:
Hi Andrea,

could you please open a support ticket for this issue? 

A non-existing or non-accessible XBRL file might indeed be caused by the virus scanner, but it is also possible that something else caused it. I guess, it is necessary to analyze the Task Engine log files to find the root cause.

Best regards,

Christoph

entry.title: Off-Cycle Payments with EC Workflows and late approvals
entry.content:
Hello All,

 

I am looking at a scenario where we have a high volume of off-cycle additional payments.  Simply put its run daily.  The off-cycles are entered into EC processed thru workflows then replicated into ECP.   The issue is that the workflows do not always get completed in time so they off-cycle is missed.  What we are looking for are ways to help identify, or even better automate an adjustment to get the of-cycle picked up and considered.

 

Any suggestions would be appreciated.

Thanks,
Todd

entry.title: Re: Printing F150
entry.content: I wasn't really worried (As long as the 'Accept as Solution' is available ‌😅‌)

entry.title: Clarification on Category Logic in SAP SuccessFactors LMS
entry.content:
Hello,

We would like to request clarification regarding the business logic recommended by SAP for the use of training categories within the Learning Management System (LMS) module of SuccessFactors.

Context:

  • We have implemented a category hierarchy (Level 1, Level 2, Level 3).
  • We have observed the following:
    • The hierarchy is not reflected in the front office filters (New Learning Experience) - As well communicated by SuccessFactors.
    • When exporting training categories, the values appear to be extracted without respecting the hierarchical order (Level 1 → Level 2 → Level 3).
    • The "Parent Category ID" field exists but does not seem to be leveraged in filters or default exports.

Main Question:

  • Should we only assign the lowest-level nodes of the hierarchy (e.g., Level 3) to training items, or is it recommended to also include intermediate levels (Level 1 and Level 2)?
  • What is the business logic promoted by SAP so that our client can align with best practices?

Objective:

We aim to ensure a consistent and optimized use of categories, both for user navigation and for reporting and exports.
Additionally, we want to ensure that our configuration is future-proof and compatible with upcoming SAP SuccessFactors evolutions, particularly regarding filters, reporting, and user interfaces.

Thank you in advance for your guidance.

Best regards,
Jeff Kellerhals

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Storie Visualization
entry.content:
Hello everyone!
I'm creating a story from a model connected to SuccessFactors. The issue I'm trying to resolve is this: when I select the "Department" dimension, it only displays the code and not the name.
In SF, the "Department" field has both the code and the name. Therefore, I don't understand why Customer Service only displays the code.
Could you help me?

entry.title: Re: Onboarding 2.0 Reporting through People Analytics
entry.content: Has anyone been able to report on candidates who have completed Onboarding and been processed in MPH (manage pending hires) with future start dates? These future hires have an employee profile in EC once hired in MPH, but they are not appearing in the UDF (user data file).  Previously with ONB 1.0, future hires are listed in the UDF after MPH, with an inactive status.

entry.title: Re: BEHAVIOR_STATEMENT_ILLEGAL error using EML for entity...
entry.content: Hello, Chuma. What would you recommend for us, we are facing same issue but a difference - we are not calling I_ServiceOrderTP from our custom RAP BO but from a standard ABAP class that serves as a application jobs. The issue occurs in just few Service Orders ( < 10 ) out of ~15 000. In the application jobs we just modify a custom YY1 fields on the Service Order Item and when we call COMMIT ENTITIES we get a shortdump. Thank you in advance, Matus
